snippet: An extensive federal examination of banks’ foreclosure practices found that managers ignored widespread errors ahead of the 2008 housing market collapse.
abstract: Housing and Urban Development Dept study of banks' foreclosure practices, which have caused a national uproar and prompted a $25 billion settlement between the banks and the government, finds that managers at major banks ignored widespread errors after the 2008 housing market collapse; banks face stiff penalties and intense public scrutiny if they fail to live up to the standards of the settlement. Photo (M)
